Pub

Let's start with the bad news. The House of Trembling Madness, on Stonegate, is not somewhere to save the pennies. There's no way to get round the fact that it's PS3.50 a pint across the board here, but telling you that now means the only way is up from here (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Sam Newsome)

Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps

Like <em>Platoon</em> that was released the year before it, I like Oliver Stone's <em>Wall Street </em>not just for its political and social relevance, but because of its enjoyable simplicity

Medea

Frayja Winterson's Medea is a personal and powerful interpretation

Barn Backstage: Medea (Week 2)

Mia de Graaf interviews Emily Thommes and Freyja Winterson, the joint directors of Medea in the Drama Barn, Friday - Sunday, Week 2.

Mr Nice

Howard Marks must be rubbing his hands with glee; not many criminals manage to have so much control over their own legacy, at least not without seeming repugnant in some way (last year's biopic of Charles Bronson comes to mind)

Rebel, Rebel

Controversial choreographer Michael Clark has reinvented just about every aspect of ballet. Mia de Graaf hears his take on the freedom of creativity (Thumbnail credit Michael Clark. All photos credit: Jake Walters)

Freshers' Food Diary

Contrary to your tutor's beliefs, man cannot live on knowledge alone. Here are some tried and tested student recipies lovingly collected by <em>Nouse</em>'s expert chefs for your benefit alone

Peter Iveson

A house game of Monopoly. A great chance to play a game properly, as being an only child and having to play by yourself soon loses its appeal (Thumbnail credit Justyn Hardcastle)

Social pariah: Charlotte Hogarth-Jones

Sainsburys pharmacy. I ask to speak to a 'medical advisor', as helpfully suggested by a laminated sign on the counter (Thumbnail credit Sam Newsome)

Camilla Jenkins

One of the advantages of York starting ridiculously late is that we have a good, long time to get used to that back-to-school feeling

Freshers by numbers

Freshers by numbers

MUSE: 12 October 2010

Welcome, first years to <em>Nouse</em>'s official Freshers' Guide. We have toiled through the nights, burning the midnight oil and depriving ourselves of sunlight to ensure that you are as prepared as possible for the adventures to come (Thumbnail credit George Lowther)

Lectures? What lectures?

It turns out UCAS may not have been entirely truthful about the whole university experience. Liv Evans offers a survival guide for the bemused, confused and slightly misused (Thumbnail credit George Lowther)

How to be indispensable

Ladies and gentlemen, intern and job applications are officially open. As we face one of the most competitive employment markets yet, India Richards investigates the best way to succeed during internships

A Nouse Night Out

By James Bithell

<em>Nouse</em>'s guide to a night out in York

Terry Waite: a man in the firing line

By James Bithell

Victoria Lee meets the man who was at the centre of a media and political storm when he was held hostage in Lebanon between 1987 and 1991

Contemporary arts' role in the education system

Artist Deborah Curtis discusses contemporary arts' role in the education system with Beth Walton (Thumbnail credit Image Credit: Richard Hubert Smith)

Lowenna Waters

The four shortlisted nominees for the Turner Prize have been announced and the exhibition is now open at the Tate Britain; that weighty, dignified and elegant building on the banks of the Thames

Arts in depth

Mia de Graaf talks to York Theatre Royal's artistic director, Damian Cruden, about where theatre stands in a world of videolinks and broadcasts

Up and coming events

"On the last day of their quarantine, a wealthy couple's house is invaded by two strangers - a sailor and a girl who might not be what she seems. And so another month of quarantine begins." Or so the synopsis of Naomi Wallace's play 'One Flea Spare' says, which starts at York Theatre Royal this month (Thumbnail credit One Flea Spare, courtesy of York Theatre Royal)

After I'm Still Here, where can satires of Hollywood go next?

In 2008, with a grizzly beard and a noticeably growing belly, actor Joaquin Phoenix announced that he'd be retiring from acting to pursue a career in hip-hop. His brother-in-law, fellow actor Casey Affleck, would document the career move and Phoenix's life at home

Made in Dagenham

40 years on from the passing of the Equal Pay Act, a film has been made that continues the Act's tradition not of feminism, but of egalitarianism

The Secret of Kells

<em>The Secret of Kells</em> is an entirely untypical specimen of a children's film

All the President's Men (1976)

A 1976 film based on the 1974 non-fiction book of the same name by Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein (who are here played by Robert Redford and a simply brilliant Dustin Hoffman), <em>All the President's Men</em> is a personal account of two journalists investigating the infamous Watergate scandal for <em>The Washington Post</em>

Hot New Designers

French-born Brooklynite Sophie Theallet wowed New York this autumn with her old world, Mexican romance inspired collection, with big printed dresses and off the shoulder dresses juxtaposed against softer lace and nude satin numbers (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Style.com)

Sofia Redgrave

What did you do this summer? Most of us will provide the generic answer: a bit of time at a beach/festival/house in the country and a lot of time doing work experience or internships. Gaining experience at fashion companies often involves hours of unpaid work. However, this is generally considered the only way to gain access to the industry

Last of the Gang to Die

By James Bithell

The Jim Jones Revue are intent on damning Tom Killingbeck's soul with rock &amp; roll

Future Sounds

Another term, another reconnaissance mission to the newest beats on the block. If you're new to <em>Nouse</em>, this is where we sniff out bands who only have self-released 7"s to their name in an attempt to make ourselves look prescient should any of them get big (Thumbnail credit oOoOO)

Nouse Playlist

So you've unpacked, had your first of many "down it fresher" moments, and maybe even managed to work out where Halifax is. These tunes should provide the perfect soundtrack to your continuing Freshers' inauguration.

Karen Elson

Bent down so that her bright red hair covered her face, Karen Elson giggled to the waiting crowd: "Sorry, bear with me! I have to tune my guitar ..."
